Idk what some of y’all are smoking, but what she said is that protests do not need to involve the use of force. In fact this is a sentiment that isn’t just advocated by her. Civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr was a staunch advocate of peaceful protesting. He stated, “Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that.” There’s a reason MLK is universally recognised as the single greatest human rights leader ever, because he knew that to get a message across to those who have wronged you, you cannot use hate, your actions cannot be fuelled by anger and most importantly you cannot stoop to the same level as your oppressors. Anger and outrage are justified emotions when a hate crime takes place. But manifesting those emotions by violent protests won’t get your voice heard, it’ll get you thrown in jail, like it has in Atlanta and New York right now.

@lilaatan this protest started in the name of George Floyd so I think it’s disrespectful that you’re supporting those who go against his family’s wishes

@lilaatan also here’s the statement that the family of George Floyd made, which was read out by their lawyer, they stated that they thanked protestors “for joining them in standing for justice, [but] we also cannot sink to the level of our oppressors, and we cannot endanger each other as we respond to the necessary urge to raise our voices in unison and outrage.”

@lilaatan George Floyd’s won girlfriend spoke out against the violence of the protests, so if you won’t take it from me, the actual protestors or the Mayor of Atlanta, take it from her, because she actually knew the man and knew what he would have wanted. Here’s the quote from her, “Waking up this morning to see Minneapolis on fire would be something that would devastate Floyd… He loved the city. He came here [from Houston] and stayed here for the people and the opportunities. … Floyd was a gentle giant. He was about love and about peace.”

@lilaatan also, the African American Mayor of Atlanta, who is female and a Democrat by the way, called out violent protestors and looters, saying, “It’s enough, We are all angry. This hurts. This hurts everybody in this room. But what are you changing by tearing up a city? You’ve lost all credibility now. This is not how we change America. This is not how we change the world. This is not a protest. This is not in the spirit of Martin Luther King Jr. This is chaos.”
@lilaatan watch this video and come back to me on that. https://youtu.be/V2n6C9YlqtQ

@bored62213 are you really going to back up your points via media coverage? you do realize that the media speaks euphemistically to trivialize & downplay what’s truly going on & twists what truly happens in their own narratives; the aggression & looting was initiated by undercover police officers to incriminate the protestors, are the protestors suppose to peacefully respond back to tear gas & rubber bullets?

@fiki.mhn “In Minneapolis, after a night of rioting, looting and setting a number of businesses ablaze on Thursday, the situation seemed calmer early Friday.

Officials there appeared to take a non-confrontational approach to people marching through the city for much of the day, despite some instances of civil disorder. But as the hours passed and protesters ignored a citywide 8 p.m. curfew, law enforcement reversed course.

The new strategy included deploying a column of National Guard troops, including armored vehicles, to respond to protests near the 5th Precinct. People had set fire to the 3rd Precinct on Thursday night, forcing police to abandon the building.

On Friday night, protesters also reportedly were seen breaking into a Wells Fargo Bank, which was also torched.” - NPR

@fiki.mhn “large crowds gathered at the CNN Center. Some protesters sprayed graffiti on the giant red letters outside the headquarters, while other smashed windows and threw rocks at the building before the crowds were pushed down the street by police. Soon after, a police vehicle caught fire near the building.” - Washington Post

@fiki.mhn “In Minneapolis ⁠ — where Floyd died Monday after a white officer pressed his knee into the 46-year-old’s neck⁠ — businesses were torched and shots were fired at police, who struggled to enforce an 8 p.m. curfew enacted after several nights of unrest.” - Washington Post

@fiki.mhn “The demonstrations took a volatile turn on Thursday night: Protesters threw fireworks at police in riot gear, and the officers fired back with projectiles, according to the New York Times. By 10 pm, the precinct building was evacuated as protesters broke in to smash equipment and lit fires.” - Vox

@fiki.mhn “Although some businesses had boarded up their windows and doors to avoid looting on Thursday, protesters made their way into big chain stores including a Target and TJ Maxx. Wednesday night had also seen looted stores, vandalized buildings, and one man shot dead” - Vox
@fiki.mhn idk what you’ve been reading but not according to reputable sources of information like the Washington Post, New York Times and Vox all of which are extremely liberal sources.

@bored62213 You also have to remember that the Minneapolis riot was peaceful until the police started spraying flammable tear gas that set the police station on fire, and firing rubber bullets into the crowd
@fiki.mhn the fact of the matter is an innocent man has been murdered and his killers need to be punished

@bored62213 You forget that there were many riots that came with that. Riots are a way to show what the rage at suppression and hate has done. George Floyd's murderers weren't passively protesting. They *murdered* a man and the only rioters damaged a store and police station to show that they would not stand for a crime that vile to go unpunished. In today's US, and with the current president, peaceful protests wont help much. I understand your point of view but this isnt a time to be thinking of "what could have been better."

@fiki.mhn they are actually. In China in 1989 they drew direct inspiration from the Civil Rights Movement in the US, learning from how peaceful demonstrations had gotten mass media attention and also global support

@fiki.mhn you’re right, they aren’t the same. In 1963, African Americans didn’t have the right to vote, the right to free speech, the right to attend the same schools as White Americans, the right to share the same public space as the White American, the right to marry a White American, restricted housing rights, the list goes on. Today they have all of those things and I’m not saying they shouldn’t be outraged and they shouldn’t protest. They should do all of those things. But there isn’t a need to stoop to the level of their oppressors, for it only justifies their racist actions and entrenches beliefs and turns public opinion against them. Even the Mayor of Atlanta, an African American women, called these violent protests a disgrace. If history has taught us anything, peaceful protests bear the most fruit and attract the most support and empathy.

@fiki.mhn in fact it was those peaceful protests in 1963 that led directly to the Civil Rights Act of 1964 which abolished Jim Crow Laws and the Voting Rights Act of 1965 which provided African Americans suffrage

@fiki.mhn you just made my point for me. It’s exactly because it isn’t China that there’ll be even more coverage. They did it once before in 1963 at Lincoln Memorial and they can do it again. In fact, with this 24/7 news cycle we live in, they’d get more coverage than they ever got back then
@bored62213 the circumstances arent the same and two different groups and protests are different and thus will act differently
@bored62213 the USA isnt China and it never will be
@fiki.mhn the media and the world was already listening before these violent demonstrations even began

@fiki.mhn no it is not. In Communist China, the most oppressive place known to man, in 1989 at Tiananmen, thousands of students held a peaceful demonstration and their movement was covered and blasted onto every global newspaper even before they were massacred
@bored62213 Not everyone is gonna be like MLK. The riot was their only way to get the media to *listen* to them
@fiki.mhn yes but MLK didn’t use or advocate the use of force

@bored62213 I understand that but the point of the protest is that their peaceful protests were so suppressed and drowned out that they felt that a riot is their only option. MLK jr also said "A riot is the language of the unheard."

text: having issues with salary and having a member of your community brutally murdered by law enforcement are completely different issues

answers.text: @ellywellyjelly nah the protests were violent to begin with. Did you see footage of protestors smashing up police cars, burning down police posts etc? Also looting instigated by police? What are you on? Why would the police bring more crime when they already have so much on their hands? Stop listening to looney conspiracy theories lmao
@ellywellyjelly totallu agree

@_turbocharged I didn't say I think the looting was ok. having said that, we don't know what started them yet. it's suspected that the start of the looting could have been instigated by moles installed by the police. either way, the protest was peaceful until police started throwing tear gas onto protestors, so the violence started with the police to begin with. is violence the answer? not really. but what can a population that can't even freely express their dissent with the institutions that failed them do other than fight back at the people who persecute them?
@ellywellyjelly looting a store isn't gonna stop police brutality

@ellywellyjelly i think that while ho ching is speaking from a place of deep-seated privilege and ignorance, her comparison shouldn’t be dismissed. these two situations are more similar than you think.

@ellywellyjelly i think we’re both pretty much in agreement, but looking at japan’s recent history, we see the same pattern as with the rest of the world: a continued trend of austerity, de-unionisation of workplaces, and police brutality against both racial minorities and workers. there may be a show of “the labour movement” supporting said bus drivers’ strike in japan, but it’s pretty much the same situation as in singapore. the theatre of NTUC and tripartite action goes on, while exploitation continues behind the curtains. wage cuts really are life and death, even in japan - this has been the case since reagan, thatcher, nakasone, and of course lee kuan yew.
@jake.lai_ either way you missed the point of my comment, which is that the comparison is inappropriate cos the context of each situation is completely different

@jake.lai_ that is true but in this case the comparison is not fair. the Japanese bus drivers have a union to fall back on and live in a homogenous society in which they don't have to worry about their voices not being heard as much as say, migrant labourers here or elsewhere, or, in the case mentioned in this post, African Americans in American society

@ellywellyjelly when the bus drivers are migrant labourers, with no real institution or organisation to back them up; when they don’t have a voice they can fall back on, salary issues become issues of life and death. you can’t untangle issues of race and economics unless you go to the root of both and split the metaphorical gordian knot.
